Alex, for the sake of argument, let me continue to take the radical 
positi=
on that embryogenic approaches are not necessary even for the 
kind of envi=
ronmentally-conditioned processes that you describe.

The environment E can=
 be conceived as just another input to a 
function, i.e. f(x,y,E)=3Dz (wher=
e E may be a vector of parameters 
that are position-dependent or not).  In=
 this way, a CPPN can build 
a pattern directly off the environment, and th=
ere is still no need 
for actual development to take place.  The bridge is =
a function of 
the environmental coordinate frame, and will thus shape itse=
lf 
perfectly to fit the environmental context.

If the environment is chan=
ging, then CPPN(x,y,E) can be be applied 
iteratively over time, either eve=
ry time step, or every time there 
is a change.  

Thus, all the advantages=
 of environmental interaction in 
developmental systems are still potential=
ly subsumed by a functional 
perspective.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com=
, "Alex" <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all
> 
>   They are some good remar=
ks about developmental approaches. I'am
> working on this approaches, I wil=
l be also at Gecco in the
> developmental approaches track :D  Using develo=
pmental encodings to
> evolve flags is not the best ways to do flags : simp=
ly evolving f
(x,
> y) =3D z is enougth, far simplier and have a much bette=
r algorithmic
> complexity. 
> 
> But those developmental encodings are not=
 meant to be used to make
> flags and only flags. They can use environmenta=
l information to
> provide a solution to a problem for differents contexts.=
 A
> developmental encoding could encode the building process of bridge,
> =
and such an encoding could works for any river length and depth... 
Or
> we=
 can imagine that each 'cells' of the embryo could have and
> information a=
 physical information, and then the embryo would 
converge
> to an optimal =
structure. With a single evolution we could solve
> severals problems. That=
's the real power of the embryogenic
> approaches. I spoke about "convergen=
ce" : that means that with an
> embryogenic approache, we simply defines th=
e solution of problem 
the
> fixed point of cells interaction. This converg=
ence, if the 
evolution
> worked well, could be achieved for a range of env=
ironmental
> conditions. Flags are only a benchmark. I'am currently working=
 on a
> new problem to show a practical example of what I call "the real 
p=
ower
> of developmental encodings". It will probably works for Gecco :D
> 
=
> Alex
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrot=
e:
> >
> > Ian, thanks for the great post.  These are indeed critical and 
=
deep 
> > issues at the core of indirect encoding.
> > 
> > I want to caref=
ully address them because I have been thinking 
about 
> > these issues for=
 a long time and they are tied into the theory 
> > behind CPPNs.  
> > 
> =
> First, note that our new journal paper that I just 
> > announced, "Compo=
sitional Pattern Producing Networks: A Novel 
> > Abstraction of Developmen=
t," gives an extensive treatment of the 
> > issues you raise in a better w=
ay than the old "Patterns Without 
> > Development."  (The journal paper ha=
s replaced "Patterns Without 
> > Development," which is no longer availabl=
e)  So you may find a 
> > better motivation in that paper.
> > 
> > In any=
 case, I will give my thoughts here in short.  I have come 
to 
> > the con=
clusion after thinking about this issue for a couple 
years 
> > that there=
 may be no representational or even computational 
> > advantage to iterate=
d developmental systems over CPPN-like 
> > functional representation.  I s=
ay "may" because I am not yet 
100% 
> > certain, but I am nearing it.  If =
I am right, this is a very 
deep 
> > and significant fact that should chan=
ge the way we are looking 
at 
> > representation through development.  
> =
> 
> > There are a few reasons for this view.  One is the simple 
> > theor=
etical fact that a single hidden layer neural network can 
> > represent an=
y function with arbitrary accuracy (a theorem by 
> > Cybenko).  From the p=
erspective of patterns, this theorem means 
that 
> > *theoretically*, ther=
e is no pattern that iterative development 
can 
> > produce that a functio=
nal description cannot describe with 
> > arbitrarily close precision.
> > =

> > Of course, that is only theory, and theory and practice are 
often 
> =
> opposed:  It still leaves open the possibility that somehow 
> > represen=
tations of certain patterns are for some reason more 
> > *compact* if they=
 are described and mapped through an iterative 
> > process.  Thus one can =
still argue they are more powerful.
> > 
> > Yet I also have come to believ=
e that that is not the case 
either.  
> > The reason hinges on an interest=
ing insight that you put like 
this:
> > 
> > "genes essentially 'pattern r=
ecognize' certain areas in the  
> > organism"
> > 
> > That is absolutely =
correct for biological organisms, and for 
> > iterated developmental syste=
ms in general.  However, the deep 
> > question is *why* should they need t=
o "pattern recognize" 
certain 
> > areas?
> > 
> > And the answer is becau=
se they need to know where they are.  In 
> > effect, in the physical unive=
rse, there is no intrinsic 
coordinate 
> > system that cells can query to =
ask their location.  Thus, they 
must 
> > develop elaborate and ad hoc way=
s of communicating to each 
other, as 
> > a group, where everyone is.  I s=
end my neighbor signals, my 
neighbor 
> > sends me signals back, and we ne=
gotiate our roles. 
> > 
> > My undoubtedly controversial contention is tha=
t the 
question "where 
> > am I?" is the ONLY reason that such negotation =
is necessary.  If 
you 
> > didn't have to ask that question, then you woul=
d not need to 
talk to 
> > your neighbors in order to determine your role.=
  Rather, you 
could 
> > just compute your role as a function of your know=
n 
> > coordinate/position in the world.  
> > 
> > That is exactly what CP=
PNs do.  Because inside a computer the 
> > coordinates of every "cell" in =
(2D or 4D or 6D or whatever) 
space is 
> > known, they do not need to comm=
unicate with each other.  Rather, 
> > they simply compute a function of th=
eir position.
> > 
> > That function in effect encompasses all the unfoldin=
g events 
that 
> > would happen in a normal iterative process, as the CPPN=
 theory 
> > says.  So if there was a symmetric gradient laid from one side=
 
to 
> > another in a growing organism through some complex process of 
> =
> communication, a CPPN simply instantiates a symmetric function 
> > inste=
ad as an analogue of the same process.  
> > 
> > Thus, I would argue that =
the CPPN likely completely subsumes 
> > iterative development, and that al=
l the fancy stuff that is so 
mind-
> > blowing that looks so important in =
devleopmental biology is 
simply a 
> > big complicated quest to answer the=
 question "where am I?" (and 
> > hence "who am I?").  In a computer, since=
 we know the "where" 
answer 
> > a priori by definition, we can wipe out a=
ll of this unnecessary 
> > complexity, in effect massively simplifying the=
 problem of 
> > represnetation.
> > 
> > My hunch is that this principle i=
s why CPPNs are producing such 
> > intricate and complex structures compar=
ed to every artificial 
> > developmental encoding that has come before.  H=
ave you ever seen 
a 
> > pattern as nuanced and intricate as the spaceship=
 produced by 
CPPNs 
> > produced by another developmental encoding?  In fa=
ct, evolving a 
> > blob or a flag-like pattern is currently considered cut=
ting edge 
> > with such systems today.
> > 
> > So I'd actually argue that=
 CPPNs are a more powerful 
representation 
> > than an iterative system be=
cause they wipe out all kinds of 
> > unnecessary complexity that results a=
t the core from simply 
needing 
> > to know where one is in the body plan.=
  And they also wipe out 
the 
> > iterations themselves.  So it's a radica=
l contrast.  In effect, 
this 
> > radical shift away from iteration and lo=
cal interaction is 
possible 
> > because CPPNs are cheating: They can know=
 the coordinate frame 
> > within which they operate a priori- something th=
at is not 
available 
> > in biology.  So it is not a surprise that when we=
 cheat we can 
do 
> > better.  
> > 
> > Thus, I am arguing an admittedly =
radical position that classic 
> > iterated devbelopment is best abandoned =
as a form of indirect 
> > encoding for evolutionary algorithms.
> > 
> > P=
lease note however, having said that, that iteration IS 
necessary 
> > for=
 developmental systems that interact with the environment 
over 
> > their =
lifetime (such as brains).  However, CPPNs can iterate in 
such 
> > a way =
just as any other system.  It only means re-querying the 
CPPN 
> > at each=
 iteration.  Thus, CPPNs do not miss this capability even 
> > when it is n=
ecessary (and it will be in the long run).
> > 
> > Therefore, my hunch is =
that CPPNs (or something quite similar) 
are 
> > the best type of abstract=
ion we will get.  The enchantment with 
a 
> > process of unfolding over ti=
me and local interaction may turn 
out to 
> > be an intuitive mistake.
> >=
 
> > ken
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Ian Badcoe <ian_b=
adcoe@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Hi,
> > > 	Can I add my opinion to the other's s=
aying that from what I 
> > read so

illiant.

> > > 	Having said that (always got to balance the praise a=
nd 
> > criticism) I 
> > > do feel that there is a little something that h=
as been missed 
in 
> > this 
> > > particular approach.  I really meant to=
 say something before, 
way 
> > > back when you posted the "Patterns witho=
ut development" work 
that 
> > > preceded this.
> > > 
> > > 	What I am ge=
tting at, is the difference between a function 
> > mapping, 
> > > however=
 complex, and an iterative system.  This difference 
seems 
> > to 
> > > m=
e to be a fairly crucial factor in the nature of 
developmental 
> > biolog=
y.
> > > 
> > > 	The reason this difference matters is something I touched =
on 
> > before:
> > > 
> > > http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/messag=
e/1818
> > > 
> > > 	albeit only "touched" on it.
> > > 
> > > 	I am having=
 some difficulty justifying this position, partly 
> > because 
> > > I hav=
en't been near the literature on any of this for over a 
year, 
> > > partl=
y because it is quite a deep point about evolvability, 
and 
> > > partly b=
ecause it is by no means proven, intuitive and a 
> > quantitative 
> > > d=
ifference rather than a qualitative one, however:
> > > 
> > > 	FIRST let m=
e illustrate the sort of iterative system that I 
> > > mean.  What I am re=
ferring to is (say) something like your 4D 
> > > connection density functi=
on (substrate configuration, I think 
you 
> > > called it).  Some sort of =
field, probably discretised into 
cells 
> > for 
> > > convenience of comp=
utation, with some value(s) stored on each 
cell.
> > > 
> > > 	NOW, the di=
fference in the two approaches is that using 
> > CPPNs, all 
> > > we will=
 do is evaluate one function (possibly very complex) 
once, 
> > for 
> > >=
 each cell in the field.
> > > 
> > > 	BUT for an iterative approach, we wi=
ll probably fill the 
> > field in 
> > > that manner as a start state, but=
 after that we will then 
iterate 
> > > over it N times applying some sort=
 of rule to update the field 
on 
> > > each pass.  It is the fact that the=
 rules act on the output of 
> > > previous stages that gives the system it=
s power.  Rules could 
be 
> > > targeted in various ways and have various =
effects, but we can 
> > imagine 
> > > the general case of recognizing som=
e pattern (either of values 
in 
> > a 
> > > single cell, or else relative=
 values in a locality of cells) 
and 
> > > changing some values in a cell =
as a result.
> > > 
> > > 	In BIOLOGY, this equates to real cells.  Every c=
ell contains 
> > the 
> > > same genes but not all genes are activated.  T=
he embryo starts 
> > with a 
> > > simple polarity (up-down) defined by a =
chemical gradient.  
Genes 
> > are 
> > > activated at certain places base=
d on the amount of chemical 
and 
> > the 
> > > gene-products produce othe=
r chemicals.  Some chemicals also 
leak 
> > from 
> > > cell to cell.  Thu=
s simple patterns of chemicals become more 
> > complex 
> > > because gene=
s essentially "pattern recognize" certain areas in 
the 
> > > organism, an=
d start producing other chemicals in response.
> > > 
> > > 	The power of a=
 system like this is, if (say) the number of 
> > legs 
> > > changes (by c=
hanging the number of repeats of a pattern at an 
> > early 
> > > stage in=
 the process), then the later stages still have a 
> > reasonable 
> > > ch=
ance of doing something sane even though the basic plan has 
> > > changed.=
  The process that would wire nerves and blood to N 
legs, 
> > > works (al=
most) as happily with N+2 legs.  This is why two 
headed 
> > > snakes are =
alive (if unfit) but two nosed Boeing 747's are 
scrap.
> > > 
> > > 	[[I h=
ave spoken about this before, and in fact I wrote (most 
> > of) a 
> > > c=
omplex philosophical web-page (called "the Manifesto for 
Evolving 
> > > A=
gents") which went into this in some depth.  Maybe I'll see 
if I 
> > can =

> > > get that up on the web somewhere, even unfinished, and the 
> > comm=
unity 
> > > might give me some useful feedback on it and get me working 
a=
gain.
> > > 
> > > 	Anyway, as you can imagine, an iterative development sy=
stem 
> > is an 
> > > order of magnitude more complex than HyperNEAT, and =
strays 
into 
> > all 
> > > out usual areas of interest/difficulty such as=
 modularity 
etc.  
> > Which 
> > > is why HyperNEAT is so clever as an in=
termediate step.  Nice 
one 
> > Ken!
> > > 
> > > 	Ian
